prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of ~8 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.

We have chosen the most compact ALMA configuration, to ensure that we do not resolve out the CO emission. The angular resolution of 2.46 arcsec corresponds to a spatial extent of ~ 17 kpc at the absorber redshift of z=0.6125.

Our estimates of the total molecular gas mass are based on the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in a sample of galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We assume a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of alpha_CO = 4.6 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1, the same as in the Milky Way, to infer the CO 1-0 line luminosity. Next, we conservatively assume that the CO rotational levels are not thermalized, as has been observed in the Milky Way. We assume that the CO 2-1 line is a factor of ~ 3 stronger than the 1-0 line, based on Milky Way data (Fixsen et al. 1999). Finally, we assume a line FWHM of 200 km/s, to obtain a peak CO 2-1 flux density of 0.6 mJy for the object. We aim to detect the emission at 5 sigma significance, at a velocity resolution of 200 km/s, i.e. matched to the line FWHM, and hence require an RMS noise of 0.08 mJy per 200 km/s channel.
We currently have cycle 2 data in hand on this object with an RMS of 0.160 mJy per 200 km/s channel. Since it will be possible to combine these data with the data from the proposed Cycle 3 observations, we only require an RMS noise of 0.12 mJy per 200 km/s channel in the Cycle 3 data (since the combined RMS noise would then be 0.08 mJy per 200 km/s).

The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of ~ 9 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.

We have chosen the most compact ALMA configuration, to ensure that we do not resolve out the CO emission. The angular resolution of 2.71 arcsec corresponds to a spatial extent of ~ 20 kpc at the absorber redshift of z=0.7821.

Our estimates of the total molecular gas mass are based on the relation between stellar mass and molecular gas mass in a sample of galaxies in the local Universe (the ALLSMOG sample; Bothwell et al. 2014). We assume a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of alpha_CO = 4.6 M_Sun (K km/s pc^2)^-1, the same as in the Milky Way, to infer the CO 1-0 line luminosity. Next, we conservatively assume that the CO rotational levels are not thermalized, as has been observed in the Milky Way. We assume that the CO 2-1 line is a factor of ~ 3 stronger than the 1-0 line, based on Milky Way data (Fixsen et al. 1999). Finally, we assume a line FWHM of 200 km/s, to obtain a peak CO 2-1 flux density of 0.80 mJy for the object. We aim to detect the emission at 5 sigma significance, at a velocity resolution of 200 km/s, i.e. matched to the line FWHM, and hence require an RMS noise of 0.16 mJy per 200 km/s channel.
We currently have cycle 2 data in hand on this object with an RMS of 0.350 mJy per 200 km/s channel. Since it will be possible to combine these data with the data from the proposed Cycle 3 observations, we only require an RMS noise of 0.18 mJy per 200 km/s channel in the Cycle 3 data (since the combined RMS noise would then be 0.16 mJy per 200 km/s). We note a low S/N feature is visible in the Cycle 2 dataset, slightly offset from the quasar. With the proposed time, the COMBINED RMS noise will be 0.16 mJy, sufficient to confirm this potential CO emission feature.

The correlator will be set up in the FDM mode in one of the bands, with 1.875 GHz and 3840 channels, and averaging by 8, to obtain a velocity resolution of ~ 8 km/s, much smaller than the expected line width. The remaining 3 bands will be set up in low-resolution TDM mode to measure any continuum emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Decades of research using absorption-line techniques have characterized the physical properties, including the surface density, chemical enrichment and molecular content, of the Universe's neutral gas. While these results undoubtedly link these absorption systems to galaxies, efforts to directly observe this association have been stymied by insufficient sensitivity and/or spatial resolution. Following on our successful Cycle 2 program, we propose to continue to use ALMA Band-4 receivers to carry out a sensitive search for redshifted CO(2-1) emission from six strong HI absorption systems at z<1. These represent the best candidates for a search for CO emission based on absorption redshift, gas metallicity, and putative galaxy counterparts. The proposed observations will allow us to (1) obtain the first detections of molecular emission from absorption systems, (2) derive the star formation efficiency in the absorbers, by comparing the SFR with the estimated molecular gas mass, and (3) compare the gas dynamics revealed through metal-line absorption, H-alpha nebular emission and CO molecular emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
